author: Helen Soteriou
title: New York: Harlem's gospel churches 'getting sick of tourists'
text: Harlem was once the overlooked New York neighbourhood that tourists just didn’t visit. But now the opposite is the case. 125th street is awash with tourists on foot or on sightseeing buses, and one of the “must see” attractions on peoples lists is attending a gospel choir service. Although gospel music is part of the heritage and spirit of the neighbourhood, some have suggested that scenes in local churches are starting to resemble a Hollywood movie. Tourists visiting have become an issue of contention, to the extent that some are now shut out of services. Harlem's gospel churches 'getting sick of tourists' Tourists outside Abyssinian Baptist Church are told that tourists are not accepted during services in August Harlem gospel tours, for example those run by Harlem Spirituals, offer visitors the opportunity to learn about Harlem’s history, with the NYC tourism website recommend they end with a “soul-stirring” music from a live choir. But entertaining tourists is not the main aim of church leaders, who mainly just want to sing and preach. This occasionally takes place out on the streets, where tourists who want to get a taste of a gospel service are more welcome. The Greater Refuge Temple Brotherhood Choir could be heard on Saturday, blocks away from my hotel, the Aloft in Harlem. Some locals also say that many of the churches are almost empty now because of the gentrification of Harlem Ralph Yates, managing director of the choir said that street services are important “because there are folks that will not come to the church so this is our medium to bring the gospel to the world’.” He said: “We don't mind tourists taking pictures when we're at the street services, however, picture taking is not allowed when services are in progress in the sanctuary’.” 'We [Harlem] are reduced to being a tourist destination' Others report that their church stopped letting tourists come to services because of the disrespect and rudeness they exhibited. For example, in some cases, as soon as the "praise and worship" or music ended, they got up and left. In some cases, as soon as the 'praise and worship' ended, they got up and left Some locals also say that many of the churches are almost empty now because of the gentrification of Harlem. People are being moved out so the churches are losing members especially since the new "young, hip, rich" generation are not going to them or joining. People are being moved out so the churches are losing members Andrew Padilla, creator of El Barrio Tours: Gentrification USA, a series of shorts on displacement in America, said: “Decades later we [Harlem] are reduced to being a tourist "destination" for the cities / countries / worlds privileged. We went from being a place those with structural power and wealth would have been frightened to end up, to a tourist destination offering them culture spice and flare. Harlem's gospel churches 'getting sick of tourists' Tourists waiting to get into a service at the First Corinthian Baptist Church “There is a true lack of appreciation of the multi-generational trauma and oppression that helped form that now very marketable ‘culture’. Ironically enough, the more that culture is marketed, the more property value rises and the harder it becomes for long time residents and small property owners, to remain.” Souleo, a native New Yorker and resident in Harlem for the past 20 years, offers the following tips for tourists. Entertaining tourists is not the main aim of church leaders “Educate yourself ahead of time. Check the church’s website, call them, or inquire with a local tour company. Some churches like Abyssinian Baptist Church list their full guidelines for visitors online. These rules should be strictly followed out of respect for the church. “If you’re unsure about something ask before you act. It is better to show consideration before the fact and not after doing something that may be deemed inappropriate. St. Aloysius church in Harlem St. Aloysius church in Harlem “Most importantly, be honest with yourself on why you’re attending a church service. If you’re going to be entertained then reconsider attending. Your subconscious motivations may cause you to act in a way that is disrespectful without you even realizing it. Attending out of innocent curiosity is one thing but do not feel entitled that the church must provide you with entertainment, a performance or any special treatment.” NYC & Company, New York’s tourist board, was unable to comment on the attraction of Harlem's churches or what it might advise tourists wanting to visit Harlem’s churches, although tour companies that visit Harlem are promoted on the NYC website.
